ptomato: Is there any risk that zone date time formatting might require a temporal constructor to close over host data? At Agoric, weâ€™ve enjoyed the separability of now() from temporal constructors and hope for that trend to continue.
content.formatted_body: ptomato: Is there any risk that zone date time formatting might require a temporal constructor to close over host data? At Agoric, weâ€™ve enjoyed the separability of now() from temporal constructors and hope for that trend to continue.

content.body: thanks for your hard work on the notes, Dan!  really appreciate it.  time at a premium today, so needed to  move

> <@kriskowal:matrix.org> ptomato: Is there any risk that zone date time formatting might require a temporal constructor to close over host data? At Agoric, weâ€™ve enjoyed the separability of now() from temporal constructors and hope for that trend to continue.

I think this is safe, Temporal constructors still don't close over any host data. FWIW you can currently already format `Temporal.ZonedDateTime` with its `toLocaleString` method; you just can't cache the expensive operations by creating a formatter object to format multiple `ZonedDateTime`, and you can't `formatRange` or `formatToParts`, so that's what this proposal is solving.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @kriskowal:matrix.org
ptomato: Is there any risk that zone date time formatting might require a temporal constructor to close over host data? At Agoric, weâ€™ve enjoyed the separability of now() from temporal constructors and hope for that trend to continue.
I think this is safe, Temporal constructors still don't close over any host data. FWIW you can currently already format Temporal.ZonedDateTime with its toLocaleString method; you just can't cache the expensive operations by creating a formatter object to format multiple ZonedDateTime, and you can't formatRange or formatToParts, so that's what this proposal is solving.

content.body: `Intl.DateTimeFormat` does close over host data, because if you construct it without a `timeZone` parameter then it internally assumes the host's current time zone, but that's a long-preexisting problem and I'm assuming you're not referring to that
content.formatted_body: Intl.DateTimeFormat does close over host data, because if you construct it without a timeZone parameter then it internally assumes the host's current time zone, but that's a long-preexisting problem and I'm assuming you're not referring to that

content.body: my preferred solution would actually remove that closing over host data in the case of ZonedDateTime. (in other cases, it wouldn't be web-compatible to change that)
I do not like "eliminates the need for developers to understand higher-order functions" as a motivation for design decisions
I really really do not like it
I think we should avoid subclassing AsyncSnapshot... it's confusing for these examples
this is a has-a relation, not a is-a

content.formatted_body:
const snapshot = new AsyncSnapshot();
snapshot.run(cb, arg1, arg2);

content.body: There's a reason why the W3C broke off from IETF--to not deal with this bureaucracy. (And then WHATWG broke off from W3C for the same reason...)
We don't realize how lucky we are bureaucracy-wise!
